holidays.name: May Day
holidays.description: An ancient celebration of spring and fertility, featuring dancing around the maypole, crowning a May Queen, and various folk festivities.
holidays.origin: Dating back to pre-Christian Europe, May Day marks the halfway point between the spring equinox and summer solstice and celebrates renewal and growth.
holidays.funFact: The maypole dance sometimes caused quite the whirlâ€”some villages banned it to avoid chaos in the streets!

holidays.name: International Workers' Day
holidays.description: A day honoring laborers and the working class, often marked by parades, protests, and demonstrations for workers' rights.
holidays.origin: Rooted in the 1886 Haymarket affair in Chicago, it became a global day to advocate for fair labor practices and worker solidarity.
holidays.funFact: Many countries use May 1 as a public holiday, turning it into a worldwide mega-focus on workers' power and rights.

holidays.name: Hug a Tree Day
holidays.description: An unusual day encouraging people to literally hug a tree to foster a connection with nature and promote environmental awareness.
holidays.origin: Started in the late 20th century as an Earth-friendly campaign to support conservation efforts and remind people of nature's value.
holidays.funFact: Hugging a tree for just two minutes can actually boost your mood and lower stressâ€”natureâ€™s own therapy!

holidays.name: Loyalty Day
holidays.description: A U.S. observance dedicated to reaffirming loyalty to the country and recognizing the heritage of American freedom.
holidays.origin: Established during the Cold War in 1958 as a counter to the growing popularity of International Workers' Day.
holidays.funFact: Loyalty Day is less well known than May Day but is officially recognized by the U.S. government every May 1.

holidays.name: Oderus Urungus Day
holidays.description: A quirky fan holiday celebrating the late lead singer of GWAR, known for his outrageous costumes and theatrical heavy metal performances.
holidays.origin: Fans of the band honor Oderus Urungus (Dave Brockie) on May 1, marking his birthdate and legendary contribution to metal culture.
holidays.funFact: Oderus was famous for battling monsters on stage and spouting wild, hilarious profanityâ€”not your typical birthday party!
